name: 3. Patient Segmentation
content:
Patient Segmentation

Methodology

To better understand patient financial and coverage profiles, we applied K-Means clustering on key features such as:

  • Income
  • Expense
  • Coverage

This unsupervised learning approach allowed us to group patients into distinct clusters, providing insights into payer-payment dynamics across different income and coverage ranges.


Cluster Insights

1.Cluster 2 – Low Income Group

  • Income: Less than 50K
  • Coverage: Up to 2000K
  • Represents patients with low income but significant insurance coverage, likely reliant on payer reimbursements.

2.Cluster 0 – Lower-Middle Income Group

  • Income: 50K – 170K
  • Coverage: Up to 2000K
  • Moderate-income patients with balanced payer support.

3.Cluster 4 – Upper-Middle Income Group

  • Income: 170K – 570K
  • Coverage: Up to 2000K
  • Higher earning segment with still substantial coverage.

4.Cluster 1 – High Income Group

  • Income: 600K – 1000K
  • Coverage: Up to 2000K
  • Wealthier patients, though coverage patterns remain consistent.

5.Cluster 3 – Very High Income Group

  • Income: 150K – 7000K
  • Coverage: Higher variability, extending significantly beyond other clusters.
  • Represents affluent patients with wide-ranging coverage policies.

Key Takeaways

  • Most patient clusters (0, 1, 2, 4) have coverage capped at ~2000K, irrespective of income.
  • Cluster 3 stands out, covering a broad income spectrum (150K – 7000K) with high coverage variability, indicating payer policies tailored for affluent segments.
  • Segmentation highlights payer dependency differences—lower-income clusters rely heavily on payers, while high-income groups show more flexibility.
